intro: Andropogon sorghum subsp. sativus, commonly known as sorghum, is a tall, warm-season grass native to Africa. It is characterized by its sturdy stalks, which are used for grain production, animal feed, and biofuel. The plant has narrow, grass-like leaves and produces dense clusters of small, spike-like flowers. It thrives in dry to semi-arid climates and is highly drought-tolerant. Its botanical features make it an important crop in many parts of the world.
